Scheme 1 Schematic illustration of the catalytic process over GdNi/ZSM-5 catalyst. Editor’s choice paper Highly nanodispersed Gd-doped Ni/ZSM-5 catalyst for enhanced carbon-resistant dry reforming of methane Bipul Sarkar a b Reena Goyal a Chandrashekar Pendem a Takehiko Sasaki c Rajaram Bal a ⁎ a Nano Catalysis Area, Catalytic Conversion & Processes Division, CSIR-Indian Institute of Petroleum, Dehradun 248005, India Nano Catalysis Area Catalytic Conversion & Processes Division CSIR-Indian Institute of Petroleum Dehradun 248005 India b SKKU Advanced Institute of Nano Technology, Sungkyunkwan University, 2066, Seobu-Ro, Jangan-Gu, Suwon, Gyeong Gi-Do, 440-746, South Korea SKKU Advanced Institute of Nano Technology Sungkyunkwan University 2066 Seobu-Ro Jangan-Gu Suwon Gyeong Gi-Do 440-746 South Korea c Department of Complexity Science and Engineering, Graduate School of Frontier Sciences, The University of Tokyo, Kashiwanoha, Kashiwa-shi, Chiba, 277-8561, Japan Department of Complexity Science and Engineering Graduate School of Frontier Sciences The University of Tokyo Kashiwanoha-shi Kashiwa Chiba 277-8561 Japan ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Gd-promoted mesoporous Ni/ZSM-5 (GdNi/ZSM-5) catalysts was prepared and evaluated in the dry reforming of methane. Addition of Gd forms GdNi5 alloy on the ZSM-5 support; the particle size of GdNi5 species supported on mesoporous ZSM-5 was found to be in the range of 2–10nm. The addition of Gd enables superior mass transfer of reactants and products while preventing the agglomeration of the Ni nanoparticles. The presence of Gd supplies the oxygen atom to neighbouring Ni site, which oxidize the accumulated coke on Ni sites. Gd promoted Ni/ZSM-5 catalyst can work till 100h without any deactivation. Ni/ZSM-5 catalyst (without promoter) shows severe deactivation due to the sintering of Ni nanoparticles during reforming reaction. Keywords Gd-promoter Ni-catalyst Coke resistance Dry reforming Syngas 1 Introduction During the last few decades, increasing global warming has become one of the major and most challenging environmental issues. It is widely accepted that the major reason for this climate change are the increasing emission of carbon dioxide in the earth’s atmosphere. Additionally, greenhouse gases except CO2, like CH4, N2O, chlorofluorocarbon (CFC) are also contributing to the global warming [1]. Thereby, the real challenge is to reduce the emission of greenhouse gases and use these gases to produce useful chemicals and fuels. The demand for the alternative energy resources is also increasing due to depletion of crude oil reserves [2]. People are looking for alternative source of energy, especially methane which has huge reserve in the form of natural gas, gas hydrates, shale gas etc. on earth’s crust [3–5]. CO2 reforming of methane is known as dry reforming (DRM), has tremendous potential interest in the researchers as it reduces two notorious greenhouse gases, methane and CO2 convert into syngas, mixture of CO and H2 (CH4 +CO2 →2CO+2H2) [6,7]. From industrial viewpoint, the produced synthesis gas has lower H2/CO ratio compare to steam reforming therefore, share the advantage for the use in Fischer-Tropsch synthesis to produce higher hydrocarbon [8]. Because the association of reverse water-gas shift (RWGS), the dry reforming technology has remained largely unrecognized. For steam reforming problem has been overcome by associating water-gas shift (WGS) reaction, but in case of dry reforming, this RWGS reaction consumes the produced hydrogen in the reaction to form water [6]. However, dry reforming catalysts deactivate very fast due to the coke deposition over the active sites of the metal and that possibly inhabits of its commercialization. It is well known that carbon deposition can occur to these conditions either by the Boudouard reaction, (1) 2CO⇆CO2 +C or by decomposition of methane. (2) CH4 ⇆C+2H2 As dry reforming of methane is an endothermic reaction, hence thermodynamically the reaction will proceed above 650°C. According to the mechanistic studies, carbon deposition via Boudouard reaction and methane decomposition for the dry reforming process is unavoidable with metallic catalysts, in particular for Ni [9–11]. Generally, Ni based catalyst account rapid deactivation due to coke deposition and sintering of active Ni sites, which desiccates Ni based catalyst form industrial application. So, preventing the deactivation of Ni based catalysts still remains a challenge to the catalysis researchers. There are several reports where researchers have shown that small Ni nanoparticles is stable against sintering for methane reforming [12–15]. Reports also revealed that it is possible to control the size of Ni nanoparticles by depositing them on Al2O3 [16,17] and SiO2 [18–20]. Alongside, Dias and Assaf found that alkali metal promoted catalyst shows sintering resistance activity [21]. In situ supported hydrotalcite-like films on Al wires with small nanodispersed nickel particles was prepared by Du et al. and these monolithic catalysts were found high resistance to coke formation and sintering in the dry reforming of methane [22]. It is reported that hierarchical porous structure with highly dispersed metallic nickel specie and presence of more basic sites with strong metal–support interaction effects are the main factors for the coke resistance and sintering of Ni nanoparticles. The role of the promoter for dry reforming of methane has also been evaluated by several groups [23–25]. Osaki et al. found DRM promoted by K enhanced adsorption of CO2, which affect to the oxidation of CHx by increasing the absorbed oxygen. Because of the high oxygen transportability, CeO2 have been used a promoter on a number of occasions [23]. The involvement of support basicity was also studied by Alotaibi et al. [26] They experienced, promoting support basicity or reducing support acidity into the zeolite framework lowered coke deposition. Influence of Gd and Nb dopants on the direct conversion of methane to syngas over CeO2 was studied by Chadwick et al. and they found that Nb doped ceria decreases the rate of methane reforming whereas Gd-CeO2 keeps the rate same as of CeO2 [27]. In another study, rare-earth metal oxide in combination with Ni based catalysts showed the lowest coke deposition in methane dry reforming [28]; Rezaei et al. found that La2O3 can effectively reduce the coke formation with Ni/ZrO2 catalyst in dry reforming of methane [29]. Whereas, Ce dopant Ni/Mg-Al catalyst also showed very good coke resistance activity in dry reforming reaction [30,31]. This enhancement of the coke resistance activity has been explained by high surface and lattice oxygen mobility, which effectively suppress the coke deposition over the catalyst. Many researchers agree that in case of lanthanide doped catalysts, the deposited carbon is filamentous carbon, where the active metal was still able to locate at the top of the carbon filament and the activity remains constant for a long run [32,33]. In the present study, we have prepared Gd promoted mesoporous Ni/ZSM-5 catalyst and found that the catalyst is stable against sintering, resulting almost no coke formation and the catalyst shows very good conversion without any deactivation till 100h. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials All reagents were purchased from the indicated suppliers and used without purification. Sodium aluminate (NaAlO2), tetrapropylammonium hydroxide solution (25% wt. in water), tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS), Poly (diallyldimethylammonium chloride) (10% wt. in water), Gadolinium(III) nitrate hexahydrate [Gd(NO3)3. 6H2O], Nickel(II) nitrate hexahydrate [Ni(NO3)2. 6H2O] were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich Co. Ethylene glycol and sodium hydroxide were purchased from Merck KGaA, Darmstadt, Germany. Deionized water was prepared with a BOROSIL® water distillation unit. All gases with purity ≥99.9% were used and purchased form Sigma-Gases, India. 2.2 Support preparation The support material hierarchical mesoporous ZSM-5 was prepared by hydrothermal method reported earlier [34]. In a typical synthesis procedure NaAlO2 was mixed with 28ml (20–25wt%) tetrapropylammonium hydroxide (TPAOH) and 28ml tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS). 80ml deionized water was added under stirring and aged for 3h at 100°C. Cationic copolymer PDD-AM (7.0g, 10wt%) was subsequently added to the solution under stirring and aged further at room temperature for 24h. The gel was transferred into an autoclave and kept at 180°C for 7days for crystallization. The obtained material was filtered and washed several times with deionized water and subsequently dried overnight and finally calcined at 650°C for 3h to remove the template. 2.3 Catalyst preparation Synthesis of colloidal Ni-Gd sol was done in the ethylene glycol medium as reported by MacDougall et al. [35] For 0.2Gd5Ni catalyst 0.43g Ni(NO3)3·6H2O and 0.01147g Gd(NO3)3. 6H2O was dissolved in a mixture of 50ml ethylene glycol and 0.4g NaOH. The solution was stirred for 30min and reduced at 160°C for 3h under reflux condition. The supported catalyst denoted as wt(%)Gdwt(%) Ni/ZSM-5 was prepared via wet impregnation method using colloidal Gd-Ni sol as the source of Ni and Gd in a similar manner as reported earlier [36]. In a typical preparation procedure, the colloidal sol (calculated with respect to support) was added with 2g of mesoporous ZSM-5 mixture under stirring. The homogeneous mixture of GdNi/ZSM-5 material was dried at 180°C followed by calcination at 750°C in the air. For comparison purposes, catalysts with various promoters (mainly lanthanum series) was also prepared and the activity was tested to the CO2 reforming of methane. Physically mixed catalyst was prepared via simple mixing of 0.43g Ni(NO3)3·6H2O and 0.01147g Gd(NO3)3 precursor with 2g of mesoporous ZSM-5 followed by calcination at 750°C for 6h in air. 2.4 Characterization techniques X-ray diffraction patterns was collected in a Bruker D8 advance x-ray diffractometer fitted with a Lynx eye high-speed strip detector and a Cu Kα radiation source (40kV and 30mA). The angle extended from 5° to 80° and varied using a step size of 0.06°, accumulating data for 60s per step. Nitrogen adsorption isotherms were measured at −196°C on BELSORP-mini II (Bel Japan Inc.) volumetric analyzers. Prior to adsorption measurements all samples were outgassed under vacuum at 180°C for 2h. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were taken with an FEI Quanta 200F instrument, using tungsten filament doped with lanthanumhexaboride (LaB6) as an x-ray source, fitted with an ETD detector with high vacuum mode using secondary electrons and an acceleration tension of 10 or 30kV. Images were recorded at various magnifications. All the Samples were analysed by spreading them on a carbon tape and coated with gold to increase the electrical conductivity. Energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) was used in connection with SEM for the elemental analysis. The elemental mapping was also collected with the same spectrophotometer. A JEOL JEM 2100 high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM) was employed to measure the size of the GdNi/ZSM-5 catalyst. Samples are mounted by dispersing on ethanol on a lacey carbon Formvar coated Cu grid. XPS spectra were obtained using Thermo Scientific K-Alpha X-Ray photoelectron equipped with Mg Kα radiation. The position of the C 1s peak at 284.8eV, was used to correct the binding energies for all catalysts. The catalyst powders were attached to conductive carbon tape for the XPS analyses. The base pressure was kept at less than 1×10−8 mbar during the acquisition. TPR of the catalyst was carried out using 10% H2 in a He flow as the reducing agent in a Micromeritics, Auto Chem II 2920 instrument. The amount of consumed H2 during the reduction was estimated on the basis of the analysis with a thermal conductivity detector. The gas flow rate was 30ml/min. The weight of the sample was 25mg, and the heating rate of TPR was 20°C/min. Nickel dispersions were obtained by pulse H2-chemisorption. The experiments were carried out in the same setup as H2-TPR. Samples were previously reduced under flowing pure H2 (10mlmin−1) at 750°C for 2h, and was then purged in He for 2h and cooled at 35°C. The pulse size was 0.5ml H2 and the time between pulses was 3min. The amount and strength of the basicity were measured by CO2 adsorption-desorption (CO2-TPD) technique using the same Micromeritics, Auto Chem II 2920 instrument. About 0.1g sample was pretreated at 680°C for 3h in presence of He gas. Catalyst was saturated with CO2 at 100°C and flushed with He to remove the physically adsorbed CO2 finally desorption of CO2 was recorded at a heating rate of 10°C/min under, He flow. X-ray Absorption Near Edge Structure (XANES) spectra of the Ni-K edge were carried out at the photon factory in the High Energy Accelerator Research Organization (KEK-IMMS-PF), Tsukuba, Japan. The measurement was made at transition mode and spectra were taken at BL-9C. The electron storage ring was operated at 2.5GeV and 450mA, synchrotron radiation from the storage ring was monochromatized by a Si (111) channel cut crystal. Ionized chamber, which were used as detectors for incident X-ray (Io) and transmitted X-ray (I), was filled with N2 (100%) and Ar (15%) N2 mixture gas, respectively. 2.5 Reforming of methane Carbon dioxide reforming of methane was carried out in a fixed bed tubular reactor in the temperature range of 650°C to 750°C at an atmospheric pressure. In a tubular quartz reactor (i. d. 8mm), 200mg catalyst was placed between two quartz wool plugged into the center. The total gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) was also varied of 10000mlg−1 h−1 to 50000mlg−1 h−1 with the feed composition of 1:1:8 of CH4:CO2:He. The catalyst was activated at 750°C with 5% H2 balance helium before the reaction for 1h. The reaction temperature was monitored using the thermocouple placed inside the furnace. The reaction products were analysed using an online gas chromatography (Agilent 7890A) fitted with a TCD detector using two different columns Molecular sieves (for analyzing H2) and PoraPack-Q (for analyzing CH4, CO2 and CO). C o n v e r s i o n ( m o l e % ) = M o l e s o f C O 2 o r C H 4 r e a c t e d ( m o l e % ) M o l e s o f C O 2 o r C H 4 i n i t i a l l y t a k e n ( m o l e % ) × 100 H 2 / C O ( m o l e % ) = M o l e s o f H 2 M o l e s o f C O 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Physiochemical properties of the catalyst The powder XRD patterns of the freshly calcined mesoporous ZSM, Ni/ZSM-5 and GdNi/ZSM-5 catalysts is shown in Fig. 1 . The d-value for mesoporous ZSM-5 in very large hence cannot measured by XRD, the same has been reported by Xiao et al. to confirm the mesoporous nature of ZSM-5 material [34]. The diffraction patterns of the support can be attributed to typical ZSM-5 which has been confirmed by the peaks at 7.9°, 8.8° and the peaks between 23.1° to 24.5° [34,37]. The peak at 44.9° demonstrate the presence of metallic Ni species (Fig. 1B) in Ni/ZSM-5 catalyst [38]. Gd promoted Ni/ZSM-5 catalyst did not show any peaks of metallic Ni or NiO, indicating the presence of very small crystal size of Ni, which is supported by HRTEM analysis (discussed later). All the catalyst along with support ZSM-5 shows type IV N2 adsorption/desorption isotherm with a hysteresis loop at a relative pressure in the range of 0.45-0.92 as shown in Fig. 2 and S1 (in supporting information). The pore size distribution of the mesoporous ZSM-5 show the mesopores at a diameter of 3–10nm (inset Fig. 2) along with a pore volume of 0.425ccg−1. The specific surface area estimated for ZSM-5 was 292.3m2 g−1 and after the loading of Ni and Gd on mesoporous ZSM-5 decrease in the surface area as well as in pore volume were noticed. High resolution scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of the GdNi nanoparticles over ZSM-5 surface is shown in Fig. S2 (A-B) (in supporting information). White spheres of about 2–10nm can be observed all over the surface, which is assigned as the Gd-Ni nanoparticles. The presence of Ni and Gd was confirmed by energy dispersive X-ray analysis (EDAX) and shown in Fig. S2C, S3 (in supporting information). Gd and Ni dispersion on the mesoporous ZSM-5 support was imaged using elemental mapping facilities available with the SEM instrument. From the elemental mapping (Fig. S2D-E; in supporting information) it is clear that both Ni and Gd are homogeneously distributed over the mesoporous ZSM-5. The TEM micrograms of GdNi/ZSM-5 catalyst are shown in Fig. 3 . HR-TEM images indicate the presence of 2–10nm GdNi5 particles on the ZSM-5 support. Particle size histogram of 0.2Gd5Ni/ZSM-5 (Fig. 3; E) catalysts reveal that 2–10nm particles are uniformly distributed over the mesoporous ZSM-5. The ring like node in the selected-area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern (Fig. 3F) confirms the presence of GdNi5 nanoparticle on support ZSM-5. The lattice fringes obtained with a d-spacing of 3.9Å corresponds to (001) plane of GdNi5 (JCPDS card 15-0428) while the lattice fringes with a d-spacing of 2.4Å correspond to the (110) plane of GdNi5 species (Fig. 4 ) in the catalyst. So, the TEM analysis confirms the formation of GdNi5 alloy. These values are in good agreement with the positive shift of Gd binding energy (discussed later) value, obtained from XPS. The core level XP spectra of Ni 2p and Gd 4d is shown in Fig. 5 and S4 (in supporting information), respectively. The Ni 2p XP spectra experienced a strong interaction between the localized 4f electron of Gd and 3d electron of Ni [39]. Due to the strong 3d-4f exchange and spin-orbit interaction, the core level Ni 2p binding energy value shows a positive shift of 0.5eV and appears at 852.8eV along with the NiO peak at 853.8eV. The binding energy value of the Gd 4d is observed at 142.5eV, which is higher than the metallic Gd by 0.4eV (comparison can be made with Fig. S5; in supporting information) [40,41]. Such positive shift of Gd ion is also reported earlier, where Gd forms intermetallic compound with Ni [42,43], Ag and Au [44]. We believe that the charge transfer from Gd to neighbouring Ni atom[42–44] has occurred for our catalyst. As Gd atom is known for its high reactivity with oxygen [45,46]; the supply of oxygen to the neighbouring metal sites occurs, which subsequently oxidizing the coke, which is deposited on Ni to form CO. The strong interaction between Gd and Ni over ZSM-5 also reduces the possible agglomeration of Ni particle. Temperature program reduction (TPR) profile of promoted and unpromoted Ni/ZSM-5 catalyst along with support ZSM-5 is shown in Fig. S6; in supporting information. Ni loaded ZSM-5 shows two distinct reduction peaks at 653°C and 792°C and we assigned that the former peak is due to the highly dispersed free NiO species in the ZSM-5 surface and the latter peak is due to the reduction of bulk Ni species where Ni react with the extra framework alumina of the ZSM-network and form NiAl2O4 type species [47]. The presence of NiAl2O4 can also be confirmed by the XPS peak at 856.0eV as suggested by Lenglet et al.[48] Whereas, 0.2Gd5Ni/ZSM-5 catalyst shows a broad peak for H2 consumption in the range between 300 and 650°C, along with a peak at 778°C. Deconvolution of the peak shows (in Fig. S6C; in supporting information) four individual peaks for different Gd-Ni species reduced at 326°C, 386°C, 473°C and 584°C with H2 consumption of 0.118, 0.187, 0.0567 and 0.078mmol/g respectively, which probably due to the different density of charge transfer from Gd to metallic Ni and which causes the positive (+ve) shift of Gd species [49,50]. So, incorporation of Gd with Ni remarkably influence the reduction behaviour of Ni species which effectively reduce the coke accumulated during the dry reforming reaction. CO2-TPD was carried out for the Ni/ZSM-5 and GdNi/ZSM-5 catalysts (Fig. S7, in supporting information) and it was found that, GdNi/ZSM-5 catalyst consumed 0.1775mmol/g CO2 whereas Ni/ZSM-5 catalyst consumed 0.1099mmol/g CO2. This indicates Gd incorporation increased the basicity of the catalyst, which is favouring the CO2 activation. Fig. 6 shows the Ni K-edge XANES of Ni foil, fresh and spent GdNi/ZSM-5 catalyst. Fresh GdNi/ZSM-5 catalyst shown the peak at 8347.5eV which is almost similar to NiO [51]. In addition, a sharp peak at 8348eV indicates the presence of Ni2+ is in a local environment, which is similar to that of a NiO of an octahedral NiO6 [52]. XANES spectra of the spent catalyst (after 5h) shows the spectra similar to the metallic Ni species. The spectra remain unchanged for the catalyst after 100h time on steam. So we can conclude that Ni species remain unchanged after 100h time on steam. Our intention was also to check whether nickel carbide or nickel carbonate formation is there? Which has been accepted as the main cause for the deactivation of the Ni containing catalysts. It has to be noticed that the addition of Gd has direct influence on the Ni particle by forming GdNi5 species which suppresses the coke accumulation on the Ni surface. 3.2 Catalytic activity and stability tests To calculate the intrinsic activity data and TOF (turn over frequency) data, reaction conditions should be determined to exclude the external and internal mass transfer limitation. Appling this condition, dry reforming were carried out at 600°C under two different testing conditions using a 5%Ni loaded and 10% Ni loaded catalyst and the results are shown in Fig. S8 (in Supporting information). It can be seen from Fig. S7, that the deviation of CO2 and CH4 conversion under all two testing conditions are less than 10%. Furthermore, the effect of external mass transfer limitation was studied experimentally (showed in Fig. S9, in Supporting information) with a fixed residence time through a variation of feed velocity, and possible effect of internal diffusion limitation was investigated by carrying out the reactions with a variable flow rate under a constant W/F ratio(0.006gsmL−1). The results indicate that both external and internal mass transfer limitations were excluded under the testing GHSV value of 10000h−1. To compare the activity of these catalysts, the same GHSV value and the amount of catalyst was used further. In addition, mass transfer limitation (internal) calculation was carried out for the highest CH4 conversion rate in the fixed bed reactor (at 750°C) as reported by Oyama et al. [53] For the spherical particles and first-order reactions with respect to the CH4 component, the Weisz-Prater criterion can be written as (3) C c w = − r A ( o b s ) ρ c R 2 D e C A s 〈 1 The result is Cwp =8.2×10−5 , indicates no internal diffusion limitation is there [53]. Dry reforming of methane was studied over GdNi/ZSM-5 catalyst and the results are shown in Table 1 . Support mesoporous ZSM-5 showed no conversion of methane (entry 1); whereas, 5%Ni/ZSM-5 (entry 4) shown 66% methane conversion with a H2/CO molar ratio of 0.93 at 750°C. These results indicate that Ni/ZSM-5 catalysts are active toward dry reforming of methane. Compare to Ni/ZSM-5 catalyst, Gd-promoted Ni/ZSM-5 catalyst showed remarkable activity, even at 750°C and a methane conversion of 83.9% (entry 5) was noticed. When the catalyst was reduced at 750°C for 1h using 5% H2 flow, the methane conversion jumps from 83% to 85% with H2/CO ratio of 0.93 (entry 6). These results indicates that Ni° (metallic nickel) is the active species for the dry reforming of methane. However, a decrease in methane conversion was observed with physical mixing catalyst (entry 7) and a methane conversion of 10% with 0.81H2/CO ratio was noticed. In our observation, the oxygen active Gd species in physically mixed catalyst facilitates the CO formation which directly decreases the H2/CO ratio. Whereas in the GdNi/ZSM-5 catalyst, the oxygen active Gd activates itself with a nascent oxygen by reducing CO2 to CO. This neighbouring oxygen oxidised the accumulated coke from the neighbouring metal atoms (Scheme 1 ). It was noted that Ni nanoparticle without Gd incorporation experienced severer sintering of Ni particle (Fig. S10; in supporting information); causes rapid loss in activity with time. Substantial amount of deposited coke was visualised and quantified as the dark spots under TEM (Fig. S10; in supporting information) and XPS, CHN analysis (Table 3) respectively for Ni/ZSM-5 catalyst. With a change of promoter, 84% and 81% methane conversion (entry 8 & 9) was observed for SmNi/ZSM-5 and LaNi/ZSM-5 respectively. But the activity of Sm and La promoted catalyst was found to decrease with time on stream (Fig. 7 ). For comparison the equilibrium conversion of CH4, CO2, and yield of water are shown in Fig. S11 (in supporting information). Under the reaction condition, with GdNi/ZSM-5 catalyst the conversion at 750°C reaches equal (with in ±5% error) to the thermodynamic conversion of methane. In addition to lower H2/CO ratio (<1), we also noticed small amount of H2O due to the reverse water gas shift (rWSG) for a small period of time (Fig. S9). The water concentration was maximum at 600°C, hence the H2/CO ratio was always smaller than 1 and at high temperatures it is close to 1 (0.93). The TOF was calculated at 600°C in order to avoid any thermodynamic limitation and tabulated in Table 2 . It can be noted that the initial turn-over-frequency (TOF) for CH4 shows substantial improvement with the addition of Gd and showed TOF value of 68.8s−1. In addition, particle diameter and TOF values compared with the reported Ni based catalyst [54] are also shown in Table 2. 3.3 Influence of reaction temperature and accessible Ni and Gd particle The influence of reaction temperature was also studied as a function of methane conversion and H2/CO ratio and shown in Fig. 8 . A gradual increase in methane conversion was noticed as the reaction temperature was increased. At 600°C the catalyst showed 36% methane conversion with H2/CO mole ratio of 0.87 and reached to 0.98 at 650°C where the methane conversion was 55%. Above 650°C the H2/CO mole ratio remained constant. The influence of Ni loading on dry reforming of methane over GdNi/ZSM-5 catalyst is shown in Fig. 9 . For all the different Ni loaded catalyst Gd loading was constant at 0.2% (wt%). The activity shows a linear increase with the temperature for all the catalyst. Whereas, 0.2Gd10Ni/ZSM-5 catalyst initially showed higher methane conversion at 600°C compare to the 0.2Gd5Ni/ZSM-5. But above 680°C the conversion decreased and at 750°C it showed 74% methane conversion. We believe that for higher Ni loading, temperature above 680°C causes agglomeration of the free Ni species (as suggested by the TEM in Fig. S12; in supporting information). This fact is in agreement with our earlier reports, where we found that the agglomeration is the main cause for decrease in methane conversion, when we increased Ni loading [55]. Our study indicates that 5wt% was the optimum Ni loading and 5%Ni loading catalysts was used for further studies. With higher Gd loaded catalyst (Fig. 10 ), we found marginal improvement in methane conversion whereas, the H2/CO ratio remained same. With higher Gd loaded catalyst, the H2/CO ratio remain between 0.81–0.87 at 600–750°C. So, 0.2wt% Gd loading was optimum to get constant H2/CO ratio of 0.98 with a considerably good methane conversion. The effect of gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) was evaluated with 0.2Gd5Ni/ZSM-5 catalyst and the results are shown in Fig. S13; in supporting information. A steady decrease in methane conversion from 96% to 41% was observed with the increase in GHSV from 5000mlg−1 h−1 to 50000mlg−1 h−1. 3.4 Influence of time on stream Fig. S14 (in supporting information) shows the effect of time-on-stream over GdNi/ZSM-5 catalyst. The Gd-promoted catalyst shows promising coke resistance activity in compare to Ni/ZSM-5 (Fig. 7) for dry reforming of methane upto 100h. A comparison results with variable amount of promoter indicates, at 750°C the 0.2%Gd promoted catalyst shows 83% methane conversion till 100h. The overall H2/CO ratio was constant between 0.97-0.99. With 0.4% Gd loading the methane conversion increases slightly to 86% with similar H2/CO ratio (Fig. 10). This result indicates that 0.2wt% Gd is sufficient to form sizeable amount of Gd-Ni clusters, which can effectively adsorb an active oxygen form CO2. This active oxygen react with C of neighbouring Ni atom (forming by Boudouard reaction to form CO) and avoid the coke deposition on Ni surface. Furthermore, we have checked the reproducibility of the results with carbon balance with the 0.2Gd5Ni/ZSM-5 catalyst, the result is detailed in Table S1. Fresh catalyst of same composition (i.e. 0.2Gd5Ni/ZSM-5) was taken each time and the conversion and carbon balance was calculate after 1h of time-on-steam. The result show relatively promising reproducibility and carbon balance almost in all the cases. 3.5 Structural stability and carbon resistance property CHN and XP spectra was recorded to analyse the coke deposition on the surface of the Ni catalyst. The amount of coke deposited over Ni/ZSM-5 and GdNi/ZSM-5 catalyst was estimated by XPS and CHN analysis and the results are shown in Table 3. The XPS data (Table 3) showed that 1×10−4 gcarbon/gcat h−1 carbon was deposited on Ni/ZSM-5 catalyst (analysed after 5h time on steam) at 750°C; which was almost ∼8 times higher than the coke deposited on GdNi/ZSM-5 catalyst. XPS characterisation reveals the existence of two kind of carbon as normal carbon-carbon bond forming species (grafitic) (CC) and oxidised carbon (CCO, CO3) deposition over Ni/ZSM-5 catalyst (Fig. 11 ) [56–58]. Which clearly indicates the Ni/ZSM-5 catalyst deactivates within 20h mainly due to the graphitic carbon and the formation of NiCO3 within the catalyst [36]. GdNi/ZSM-5 catalyst shows excellent coke resistance behaviour compare to Ni/ZSM-5 catalyst and encountered only 4.7×10−5 gcarbon/gcat h−1 carbon deposited after 50h time on steam, which is almost 136 times lower compare to Ni/ZSM-5 catalyst. Although the amount of coke over GdNi/ZSM-5 catalyst is negligible compared to Ni/ZSM-5 catalyst, but it did not affect the high activity of the catalyst with time on steam (as suggested by Fig. S14; in supporting information) upto 100h. O2-TPO of the catalyst also shows no coke deposition over the GdNi/ZSM-5 catalyst, Fig. S15 (in supporting information). The amount of coke deposited on GdNi/ZSM-5 after 100h is only 7.8×10−5, this result clearly suggests the involvement of active oxygen from Gd species which playing the crucial role by oxidizing the deposited coke to carbon monoxide. TEM images of the spent catalyst revealed that the size of the GdNi particle are almost the same after 100h reaction (Fig. S16; in supporting information). Normally the size of the Ni particles increases (due to sintering) for the deactivated catalyst. We also measured the BET surface area for the GdNi5 catalyst after 100h (Table 1, entry 10), and found that the surface area of the catalyst remained same. 4 Conclusion Dry reforming of methane was studied over Gd promoted Ni/ZSM-5 catalyst prepared via colloidal nanoparticle rout [35]. The following conclusion can be drown from the present study. Gd promoted Ni/ZSM-5 shows high activity toward dry reforming of methane at 750°C. It was found that, among the various promoters (of lanthanum series), Gd effectively suppress the phase transformation to form NiAl2O4 and effectively stabilize the Ni nanoparticle over mesoporous ZSM-5. Whereas, Ni nanoparticle without Gd incorporation show sintering of Ni particle and decrease its activity due to rapid carbon deposition. Formation of GdNi5 alloy with particle size of ∼2–10nm was noticed on mesoporous ZSM-5 support. The lattice fringes with a d-spacing of 3.9Å and 2.4Å is in well accordance to (001) and (110) plane of GdNi5 (JCPDS card 15-0428). This observation is also in good agreement with the positive shift of 0.4eV binding energy of Gd and 0.5eV for Ni. The Gd Ni/ZSM-5 catalyst shows very high activity till 100h at 750°C without any coking and sintering of active metals. It was believed that the strong interaction and charge transfer between Gd and Ni suppress the C accumulation and Ni sintering in methane dry reforming. Overall, this sintering and coke resistance Gd promoted Ni/ZSM-5 catalyst can be used particularly for the production of syn gas without any coke formation. Acknowledgements B. coredata.dc:description: Gd-promoted mesoporous Ni/ZSM-5 (GdNi/ZSM-5) catalysts was prepared and evaluated in the dry reforming of methane. Addition of Gd forms GdNi5 alloy on the ZSM-5 support; the particle size of GdNi5 species supported on mesoporous ZSM-5 was found to be in the range of 2–10nm. The addition of Gd enables superior mass transfer of reactants and products while preventing the agglomeration of the Ni nanoparticles. The presence of Gd supplies the oxygen atom to neighbouring Ni site, which oxidize the accumulated coke on Ni sites. Gd promoted Ni/ZSM-5 catalyst can work till 100h without any deactivation. Ni/ZSM-5 catalyst (without promoter) shows severe deactivation due to the sintering of Ni nanoparticles during reforming reaction.
coredata.dc:title: Highly nanodispersed Gd-doped Ni/ZSM-5 catalyst for enhanced carbon-resistant dry reforming of methane
coredata.prism:publicationName: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical
